CommentText: The Republicans who make these kinds of arguments seem to be oblivious to the fact that the US is pretty much the most difficult country to immigrate into there is. If you want to go there as a tourist from an ESTA country, it's pretty easy with a small fee and so long as you stick to the rules on how long you're allowed to be there and don't try to work etc. but if you wanted to go there permanently, it's like a 15 year process that requires a lot of money and hoops to jump through. It is far from as easy as just jumping a wall. Even if you did jump the northern or southern border, you would really not want to stray too far from the border, as getting caught is incredibly easy. Hell, I was once on holiday in Canada (I'm British) and accidentally strayed into the US while sailing around Lake Ontario in the Thousand Islands region. The border force were on me like a hawk. They didn't do anything other than tell me I was in US waters and to turn around, which I did, but if I were up to anything dodgy like intentionally trying to jump the border, it would take one hell of a lot of planning to get around them.

CommentText: Legal immigration is not difficult. I filed for my Filipina wife beginning in 2007. @@xxxxxxxxx   I am a female lawyer working in finance in the City. If you're not from England - this means in the financial district in London, UK. 

At my firm and all other "elite" firms (in the top 10 worldwide) around 50% of the lawyers are male and around 50% are female. On average, there are slightly more female lawyers than male lawyers at the top 10 firms. 

In my field men do not push themselves harder than women, they do not work longer hours and they do not take on harder tasks. The number of hours that men and women at my firm work is equal - generally 9am to somewhere between 10pm and 4am. Deals are spread evenly between all the lawyers regardless of gender. Both genders push themselves equally as hard. I know this because I have worked in the field alongside hundreds of lawyers, both male and female, for almost a decade.

Those men who have nervous breakdowns or commit suicide in the profession are doing exactly the same work as the women. They are just less able to cope. Their mental resilience is weaker on average. I don't know why. Most of my male colleagues are however just as resilient as the women. 

For this, and other reasons, male transactional lawyers at "elite" firms do not "excel more in their line of work" as you so puzzlingly allege.

In fact part of this is connected to the male tendency that you mention to, on average, take greater risks than women. As lawyers this can translate into poor attention to detail and hasty, sloppy drafting, or a sudden move in negotiation that hasn't been approved by the client. 

This relative vulnerability among male lawyers on average is well known. Get yourself to a networking event if you can score an invite somehow, and find out for yourself.

It amuses me to see someone with zero experience in my field attempt to make bold statements about it.

They discharged us and then they called us again as my newborn had newborn jaundice. They could have kept us for a day instead of calling us literally 2 hours after discharge, so they can charge us more.
We ended up paying 20,000 out of pocket for light therapy and all. Even though we both work and have insurance. And she wants everything handed out to her for free. Ridiculous.
